text.content:
NABERT = NAQANet except QANet is replaced by BERT. For Arithmetic section, they needed a number’s representation, rather than just the individual byte pairs that make it, so they try (1) the first byte pair’s encoding, and (2) pooled encoding via self-attention.
NABERT+ = NABERT + some “Standard” numbers always available for the arithmetic module (see above in NAQANet). Eg. [1,100,10..] will always be available along with all the extracted numbers from passage and question. Since they don’t have a contextual embedding, their static embedding is trained and used always.
“Upon adding 100 as a standard number, we got a 12% EM (exact match) boost on number answer types and 8% overall”.
So they don’t have number embeddings in the same way as I do, i.e. projecting a number onto a continuous space. They do make use of number embeddings that bert gives them, but it still sees strings as inputs, not numbers.

text.content:
Paper isn't relevant but references are.

3 types of estimation have been identified: numerosity; computational; and measurement (Hogan & Brezinski, 2003; Siegler & Booth, 2004; Siegler & Opfer, 2003). 
- Numerosity = ability to estimate the number of items in a particular array without taking the time to explicitly count them. For example, a scientist’s ability to accurately estimate the number of microbes in a microscope viewfinder requires numerosity.
- Computational estimation = ability to determine an approximate output value for a given formula or computation without actually “crunching” the numbers.
- Measurement estimation = ability to determine (without using a measuring tool) a value such as length, weight, volume, etc. for a particular object or task (Hogan & Brezinski, 2003).

Length estimation involves applying increasing numerical values to increases in length and mapping from number to length and length to number (Joram et al., 1998)

text.content: This paper measures the NCS acquired by existing neural language models using a masked numeral prediction task as an evaluation task and proposes methods to reflect not only the symbolic aspect but also the quantitative aspect of numerals in the training of language models, using a loss function that depends on the magnitudes of the numerals and a regression model for the masked numal prediction task.

text.content: This paper conducts a comprehensive analysis of models from two broad classes of the most powerful sequence-to-sequence architectures and finds notable differences in their ability to resolve mathematical problems and generalize their knowledge.

text.content: The experiment results show that NumGPT outperforms baseline models (e.g., GPT and GPT with DICE) on a range of numerical reasoning tasks such as measurement estimation, number comparison, math word problems, and magnitude classification.

text.content: This work proposes to augment sparse Transformer blocks with a dense attention-based $\textit{global memory}$ of length $M$ ($\ll L$) which provides an aggregate global view of the entire input sequence to each position, and empirically shows that this method leads to substantial improvement on a range of tasks.
